newsitem.title: LEBANON: Pope praises religious tolerance in Lebanon.
newsitem.headline: Pope praises religious tolerance in Lebanon.

text.p: Pope John Paul took his message of Moslem-Christian reconciliation into the battle-scarred heart of Beirut on Sunday, telling a huge crowd that Lebanon was an example to the world of religious co-existence.
Speaking on his first visit to the Middle East, he called for "a just and lasting peace" in the region that would respect the rights and aspirations of all.

The crowd estimated at more than 300,000 people -- more than 10 percent of Lebanon's population -- gave the Pope a massive welcome as he celebrated mass on a seafront esplanade on the second day of his 32-hour visit.

Thousands more overflowed into the streets and tens of thousands lined the Pope's 30 km (20 miles) route to the capital through the Christian heartland north of Beirut in a welcome that surpassed even Saturday's enthusiastic turnouts.
The bulletproof Popemobile was covered in rose petals and rice flung by flag-waving crowds by the time it reached the capital and got stuck for half an hour in the seafront throng.

"Your presence is a motivation for us to continue with the reconstruction process and a sign that Lebanon will become independent, sovereign and enjoy the power of free decision," Cardinal Nasrallah Sfeir, the Maronite patriarch, told the Pope as the mass began.

Speaking within sight of the former Green Line battlefront where Moslem and Christian militias fought during the 1975-90 civil war, John Paul said Lebanon had an historical mission down the centuries as a country of many religious faiths.
"Lebanon has shown that these different faiths can live together in peace, brotherhood and cooperation," he said.
"It has shown that people can respect the rights of every individual to religious freedom, that all are united in love for this homeland which has matured over the centuries," he added.
Several Moslem politicians attended the mass, including Sunni Moslem Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri and Shi'ite Moslem leader Nabih Berri, who is speaker of parliament.
Veiled Moslem women could also be seen in the crowd.
John Paul sought to encourage the Christian minority, many of whom complain bitterly of isolation by pro-Syrian governments since the war, but he did not address their specific grievances.
"I am certain that the sufferings of the past years will not be in vain; they will strengthen your freedom and unity," he told them.
He urged the Lebanese to go forward "along the path of peace and friendliness, with mutual respect for people's dignity and freedom."
On Saturday, the Pope told a cheering crowd of young people not to erect new walls dividing Lebanon but to build bridges to other communities and get involved in political life.

In what appeared a bow to Moslems who want the Pope to demand the withdrawal of Israeli troops from a south Lebanon occupation zone, the Pope expressed his sorrow for the sufferings of the people of Sidon and Tyre, the main cities of south Lebanon.

"I ask Jesus today to put an end to these sufferings. And I also implore the grace of a just and permanent peace in the Middle East in respect for the rights and aspirations of all," he said at Sunday's mass.
